title.narrative: Output 2.1: Training courses relevant to the work of the Investigative Team undertaken for NPOs

description.narrative:
Number of NPOs trained on basic investigative, analytical and specialized skills relevant to the work of the Investigative Team conducted through training courses delivered by international experts. This should include an effort to achieve gender balance in the identification of NPOs targeted to receive capacity building.
This will be verified and qualified through collecting an official record of training; impact of the capacity building intervention on the targeted beneficiaries (e.g. pre/post evaluation); satisfaction with the capacity building programme (e.g. feedback form or interview); and six month follow-up to determine application of the intervention.

title.narrative: Output 2.1: Training courses relevant to the work of the Investigative Team undertaken for NPOs

description.narrative:
Number of NPOs trained on basic investigative, analytical and specialized skills relevant to the work of the Investigative Team conducted through training courses delivered by international experts. This should include an effort to achieve gender balance in the identification of NPOs targeted to receive capacity building.
This will be verified and qualified through collecting an official record of training; impact of the capacity building intervention on the targeted beneficiaries (e.g. pre/post evaluation); satisfaction with the capacity building programme (e.g. feedback form or interview); and six month follow-up to determine application of the intervention.

comment.narrative: Q4, 2019: 0 NPOs have been trained, as there is currently no NPOs on the Investigative Team. This is anticipated in Q1 2020.

title.narrative: Outcome 1: Investigative judges, their teams and related forensic experts employ the capacities acquired, independently and jointly with UNITAD, to advance common investigative priorities

description.narrative:
Number of investigative and forensic activities (e.g., scanning, cataloging and archiving Da’esh case files and material, completing INTERPOL notice requests, taking witness statements, undertaking link chart and CDR analysis, DNA analysis) across investigative priorities on which UNITAD and the beneficiaries cooperate and jointly employ the capacities learned.
For an ‘investigative activity’ to be counted, it needs to satisfy two criteria. First, the activity needs to fit directly within the scope of the training one or more participants received under the project and then applied in practice. Second, it needs to be ‘new’, in that, it is the first time the targeted beneficiary(ies) and UNITAD jointly cooperate. How this is counted in relation to per participant and per training will be evaluated in the assessment.

title.narrative: Outcome 1: Investigative judges, their teams and related forensic experts employ the capacities acquired, independently and jointly with UNITAD, to advance common investigative priorities

description.narrative:
Number of investigative and forensic activities (e.g., scanning, cataloging and archiving Da’esh case files and material, completing INTERPOL notice requests, taking witness statements, undertaking link chart and CDR analysis, DNA analysis) across investigative priorities on which UNITAD and the beneficiaries cooperate and jointly employ the capacities learned.
For an ‘investigative activity’ to be counted, it needs to satisfy two criteria. First, the activity needs to fit directly within the scope of the training one or more participants received under the project and then applied in practice. Second, it needs to be ‘new’, in that, it is the first time the targeted beneficiary(ies) and UNITAD jointly cooperate. How this is counted in relation to per participant and per training will be evaluated in the assessment.

comment.narrative: *Q4, 2019: 25 investigative or forensic activities across three investigative priorities (Sinjar, Mosul and Tikrit) on which UNITAD and the beneficiaries cooperate.

title.narrative: Outcome 2: National Professional Officers (NPOs – Iraqi Nationals) employ basic investigative, analytical and specialized training skills in their day-to-day work with the Investigative Team

description.narrative:
Outccome indicator: Number of investigative and analytical activities (e.g., scanning, cataloging and archiving Da’esh case files and material, completing INTERPOL notice requests, taking witness statements, building structural investigations on Da’esh leadership, undertaking link chart and CDR analysis) across investigative priorities on which the NPOs work an employ the capacities learned.
For an ‘investigative activity’ to be counted, it needs to satisfy two criteria. First, the activity needs to fit directly within the scope of the training one or more participants received under the project and then applied in practice. Second, it needs to be ‘new’, in that, it is the first time the targeted beneficiary(ies) has applied it. How this is counted in relation to per participant and per training will be evaluated in the assessment.

title.narrative: Outcome 2: National Professional Officers (NPOs – Iraqi Nationals) employ basic investigative, analytical and specialized training skills in their day-to-day work with the Investigative Team

description.narrative:
Outccome indicator: Number of investigative and analytical activities (e.g., scanning, cataloging and archiving Da’esh case files and material, completing INTERPOL notice requests, taking witness statements, building structural investigations on Da’esh leadership, undertaking link chart and CDR analysis) across investigative priorities on which the NPOs work an employ the capacities learned.
For an ‘investigative activity’ to be counted, it needs to satisfy two criteria. First, the activity needs to fit directly within the scope of the training one or more participants received under the project and then applied in practice. Second, it needs to be ‘new’, in that, it is the first time the targeted beneficiary(ies) has applied it. How this is counted in relation to per participant and per training will be evaluated in the assessment.

comment.narrative: Q4, 2019: 0 investigative and analytical activities across three investigative priorities (Sinjar, Mosul, Tikrit).

title.narrative: Output 1.2: Hands-on capacity building undertaken to address select needs of the investigative judges, their offices and forensic experts

description.narrative:
Output indicator: Number of investigative judges, their teams and forensic experts within key locations impacted by Da’esh in Northern Iraq (Nineveh, Salahuddin, Kirkuk, and KRG), and Baghdad receive capacity building in line with the identified needs resulting from the assessment. This should include an effort to achieve gender balance in the identification of investigative judges, their teams and forensic experts to receive capacity building.
This will be verified and qualified through collecting an official record of training; impact of the capacity building intervention on the targeted beneficiaries (e.g. pre/post evaluation); satisfaction with the capacity building programme (e.g. feedback form or interview); and six month follow-up to determine application of the intervention.

title.narrative: Output 1.2: Hands-on capacity building undertaken to address select needs of the investigative judges, their offices and forensic experts

description.narrative:
Output indicator: Number of investigative judges, their teams and forensic experts within key locations impacted by Da’esh in Northern Iraq (Nineveh, Salahuddin, Kirkuk, and KRG), and Baghdad receive capacity building in line with the identified needs resulting from the assessment. This should include an effort to achieve gender balance in the identification of investigative judges, their teams and forensic experts to receive capacity building.
This will be verified and qualified through collecting an official record of training; impact of the capacity building intervention on the targeted beneficiaries (e.g. pre/post evaluation); satisfaction with the capacity building programme (e.g. feedback form or interview); and six month follow-up to determine application of the intervention.

comment.narrative: Q4, 2019: No training needs assessment, or training or capacity building has been delivered by UNITAD to the targeted beneficiaries; and they are unlikely to have received any significant, sustained and hands-on support from other entities.

title.narrative: Output 1.1: Training needs assessment covering the capacities and training needs of investigative judges, their teams, and forensic experts

description.narrative: Output indicator: Training needs assessment report that includes a detailed assessment of capacities and training needs of investigative judges, their teams and of forensic experts within key locations impacted by Da’esh in Northern Iraq (Nineveh, Salahuddin, Kirkuk, and KRG), and Baghdad. This will include a plan for training activities and delivery timeline.

title.narrative: Output 1.1: Training needs assessment covering the capacities and training needs of investigative judges, their teams, and forensic experts

description.narrative: Output indicator: Training needs assessment report that includes a detailed assessment of capacities and training needs of investigative judges, their teams and of forensic experts within key locations impacted by Da’esh in Northern Iraq (Nineveh, Salahuddin, Kirkuk, and KRG), and Baghdad. This will include a plan for training activities and delivery timeline.

comment.narrative: 2019, Q4: Limited understanding of targeted beneficiary capacity needs; secured anecdotally through speaking with them, but not fully assessed. No such assessment has been done by other actors.
